Actual Bone-In Ribs at Burger King
I’ve seen some reviews about the new Ribs at Burger King. I knew that I needed to give them a try and was expecting the very worst . But, it’s actual real food, complete with bones, at a fast food restaurant. Why not give them a try?
If the Creepy King Didn't Give It Away, the Sack Your Ribs Come In Should, You're Not In Texas
The 6 piece order of Ribs as a combo meal (with fries and drink) was a little pricey at $7.59. You could add on two more ribs to make an 8 piece meal for $8.99. Dave and I weren’t sure what the best plan should be, so we initially thought to split a 6 piece combo and then get something else as a backup plan (it was lunch and we were hungry). But, when Dave ordered, the cashier revealed that you can add on a 3-piece order of ribs to any combo meal for $2.59. Not too expensive, so we both went that route.
The first rib that I tried was actually pretty incredible. It’s the one in the top picture and it was actually quite juicy. It was smoky tasting and didn’t need any sauce. It slid right off the bone. I was impressed. And Dave was looking at me like I was insane because his rib wasn’t quite that good. My second rib was a bit closer to what I expected. It was a bit tougher and drier, so I went for the barbecue sauce. Burger King’s barbecue sauce is a little spicy, but a little honey sweet. Not too bad as sauces go, but nothing amazing. The slightly drier rib plus sauce wasn’t bad. The third rib was somewhere in between the two, a little moist, but not as amazing as the first. Dave’s sack of ribs had this striation of juiciness, as well. All in all, we were pretty happy. For fast food, this was real food like you might cook yourself and really wasn’t that bad. Sure, it’s nowhere near as good as Texas barbecue or really most other authentic spots, but it’s not bad if you’re craving some barbecue.
The Three Little (St. Louis) Ribs
I have this theory that fast food in cities is generally not prepared up to the same standards as fast food outside of larger metropolitan areas. There is a lot of variability in fast food, even though so much care has gone into controlling everything. I mean, based on personal experience, the Taco Bell Shrimp Tacos that I had in both Philadelphia and Bala Cynwd didn’t compare to those had further away from the city limits. So, not sure if I’m blessed to have fast food franchisees who actually follow the instructions or not.
Here’s the end all argument for me: Burger King’s actual Ribs are better than a McDonald’s McRib . Sure, it would be nice to take the rib meat and add some onions and pickles, but real pork to pressed pork patty, the real pork comes out on top. And while McDonald’s keeps pussyfootin’around with whether the McRib is on the menu or retired or whatever, Burger King has decisively put these things on the menu. A clear winner.
In any case, these ribs weren’t really that bad. In fact, one of the three ribs was actually pretty good and, if I could be guaranteed they’d all taste like that, I’d probably eat these on a regular basis. Sure, Burger King is not a small mom and pop establishment in Texas cranking out the magic to a select crowd in the know, but you know that by stopping there in the first place, you can’t expect much more than that. All in all, I’d eat them again.
The Third Dimension
Two Integrals. Really not that bad for fast food and one of the ribs was really decent, with fall off the bone tenderness. If all three were that good, the rating would be much higher.
